ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course was an unbelievable experience. The discussions were rich, my mind was pushed, i would definitely recommend this course
This was a great immersion learning experience, and the range of organizations and individuals we were able to talk to was unlike other experiences I have had at FES.

Justin did a phenomenal job leading this class. The field trip was a highlight of my time at FES this semester and having the chance to visit Wyoming put everything we discussed in the classroom into perspective.

This course was an incredible opportunity to consider environmental and social change in a place - through readings, field study, and writing. Much of what we learned could only be accomplished through an in-depth case study, and Justin crafted a cohesive and fascinating schedule of stakeholders with whom we met.

A fantastic field course in the West, which fills a vital gap in the FES curricular offerings. Professor Farrell did an excellent job of framing a Wyoming experience that highlighted the many different, conflicting worldviews that must be understood to make environmental and social progress in the West. The field component was well complemented by reflective papers that helped students reflect upon lessons from the field and coalesce them into a more complete understanding of western issues. This on the ground training is really an essential component for helping to translate other coursework into a usable context on the ground. Would highly recommend to others - a highlight of my time at FES!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trip - but all of the readings and assignments made the class much more engaging
The field trip to Wyoming was very valuable to provide context to my own career interests and also to understanding the intersection of social and environmental issues in the broader perspective.

There was a strong sense of community within the class, and the range of backgrounds of students in the class made conversations really valuable. Also, being able to connect the threads of regional politics (rather than staying in just one location) was unique.
The field trip to Western Wyoming, Prof. Farrell, and the friendships made with other people in the class.
Meetings with a variety of stakeholders, making lasting friendships with my classmates

The field, and the patchwork of stakeholders we met with. Stepping back and looking at all of the folks we met with within one landscape greatly contributes to my growth in understanding diverse stakeholders and perspectives on western environmental issues. It was also great to have a diversity of backgrounds of students participating in the course.

This was a phenomenal course. The field trip was by far one of the most professionally relevant and interesting things I've done while at F&ES, and the pacing of assignments, research, readings etc. supported the overall course structure. The group of students was quite varied, which made for really productive discussions and a great dynamic during the trip. While a case study / overview of the region and its issues, the way the course was led allowed each student to pursue their individual interests while still benefiting from the wide variety of interconnected topics, stakeholders, and issues.

The field component of this corse was invaluable. We engaged in participatory learning with the communities of our study. As a student interested in studying and working in the American West, this course provided unparalled exposure to some of the stakeholders in the region, allowing for ongoing dialogue beyond the classroom readings. This was the best course in my FES career.

The field trip was the centerpiece and highlight of the course. I think the small size and careful grouping of students with complementary interests played a big role in the success of the course as well.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Class times. Would have enjoyed to participate in discussions....
I wish we had slightly more communication prior to the trip about what we were doing.
Probably put the open day in the middle of the trip rather than at the end.
I would appreciate more concrete deadline for papers etc.
A lot was really crammed into a small amount of time and the field trip was exhausting.

A free / rest day during the middle of the field trip, not the beginning, would have helped break up the intensity a bit. Also, having a scheduled class time (even if it didn't meet every week) would help people plan around other courses more effectively.
I think meeting a little more regularly, maybe every other week, before and after the trip might help by providing more space to discuss pre-trip readings and post-trip projects.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Strong
This course was entirely discussion based, it could be interesting to have a few framing lectures for those of us with limited social science experience.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Really great human perspective aspect
The field trip to Wyoming was very valuable to provide context to my own career interests and also to understanding the intersection of social and environmental issues in the broader perspective.

My sense is that many students at FES are interested in the human dimensions of environmental management, yet there seem to be fewer courses that focus in this area. This course did a great job of opening up the complexities of local politics to our class.
I have always been interested in the west and I am so very happy this class was offered.
This course was designed to accommodate both natural and social scientists specializing in the American West.

This course provided an opportunity to tie back my legal education and technical skills learned at FES into the western social and political issues that I hope to apply these skills to in my future career.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To relate to humans better and understand important problems
The field trip to Wyoming was very valuable to provide context to my own career interests and also to understanding the intersection of social and environmental issues in the broader perspective.

I hope to work in the west and I think it's critical to understand the politics of the region. This course also gave me important listening, questioning, and analysis skills that will I will undoubtedly carry with me to my future endeavors.

Professor Farrell is the foremost expert in the area and his pedagogy and leadership were hallmarks of the experience. His disciplinary knowledge is distinct in FES. Taking this course was crucial to my training as an environmental scientist and will continue to hold significance throughout my career.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.. exceeded
Yes - exceeded them.
Yes - probably more so.
YES 100% and more!
Above and beyond!

Yes, the knowledge and experience exceeded my expectations. Getting to study these issues on the ground and meet the people working on them or affected by them really helped affirm the path I am on and challenged some of the professional expectations I have for myself.
I learned far more than I expected- this is largely due to the nature of experiential education and the quality of my peers.
Absolutely!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: All advantages
I really enjoyed the short group project we completed. We all provide different perspectives and learned from each other's experiences. My team members worked hard and delivered high quality work.
I thought group work functioned well in this course. During the field trip proper we were constantly traveling or working in groups, which helped me learn a lot from my peers.

Group research project was helpful and allowed us to interact with each individual's interests and learning style. It was good to do groups for the overview research, but helpful to be able to focus on our individual interests in the other assignments.
It provided a platform to bring together differing perspectives toward a shared goal of mutual education.

The workgroups were well designed with students with complementary skillsets to help process the information from different perspectives. They also helped prepare group members for the field trip by allowing everyone to have an area of expetise.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Just take it and be totally engaged
A great experience!
Take this course!
Take it. Justin is an incredible resource and you will have such a wonderful time.
Best course you'll take - by far!

Do it! This has been one of the best courses I have taken while at Yale. All components (class, discussions, readings, the field trip, and individual assignments) work extremely well together to make for a dynamic, challenging, and fun experience.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in learning more about the West or engaging on Western environmental issues.
